Pictures: Public, dignitaries gather for service

President Barack Obama said today that America stands with the city of Boston after the deadly terror bombing attacks. Reuters Photo
Mayor Thomas M. Menino arrived in a wheelchair due to his broken leg but stood later to speak at the service. CJ Gunther / EPA
President Obama and his wife Michelle arrived at the interfaith memorial service for the bombing victims. Reuters Photo
A look at the crowd in attendance for "Healing Our City: An Interfaith Service" for the bombing victims. Jewel Samad / AFP / Getty Images
President Obama spoke at Cathedral High School with Mayor Thomas Menino and Gov. Deval Patrick. AP Photo
US Rep. Markey and Gov. Patrick greeted President Obama and Michelle Obama at Logan Airport. Reuters Photo
Hundreds of people lined the streets outside the Cathedral of the Holy Cross. Stan Honda / AFP / Getty Images
Marathon runner Nathan Finney of Boston and his daughter, Mckenna, 5, outside the Cathedral of the Holy Cross. Stan Honda / AFP / Getty Images
Cellist Yo-Yo Ma rehearsed before today's interfaith service at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross in Boston. David L. Ryan/ Globe Staff
A choir filed into Boston's Cathedral of the Holy Cross before today's interfaith healing service. David L. Ryan/ Globe Staff
Law enforcement personnel sat among congregants at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross. David L. Ryan/ Globe Staff
Daughters of Mary of Nazareth waited in line for tickets to the interfaith service today. David L. Ryan/ Globe Staff
People lined up early for free tickets to the service at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross in Boston. David L. Ryan/ Globe Staff

    A show of character

    Far from reeling, Boston is firmly on its feet. Far from numb, Boston is openly expressing its grief.
